summary: An FBI intake document from November 16, 2021, recording a call from a nurse practitioner who cared for Jeffrey Epstein in 2000. The caller reported having 'significant information' about Epstein and witnessing Ghislaine Maxwell visit him, but declined to provide details over the phone, citing HIPAA concerns and a desire to speak in person with the district attorney's office.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FBI intake report; a nurse practitioner cared for him in 2000 while he was staying at the Surrey Hotel in Manhattan.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Reported to have visited Jeffrey Epstein while he was under the care of the nurse practitioner in 2000.

connections.description: Maxwell visited Epstein while he was under medical care at the Surrey Hotel in 2000, as reported by the nurse practitioner.

events.title: Epstein's Medical Care at Surrey Hotel
events.description: A nurse practitioner cared for Jeffrey Epstein for at least 24 hours while he was staying at the Surrey Hotel in Manhattan. During this time, the nurse 'experienced' what the victims went through and observed a visit from Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Nurse Practitioner Reports to FBI
events.description: A nurse practitioner called the FBI National Threat Operations Center to report her 2000 encounter with Jeffrey Epstein, stating she had 'significant information' that could help the district attorney's office but wanted to speak in person.

keyFacts: A nurse practitioner who cared for Jeffrey Epstein in 2000 contacted the FBI in 2021, claiming to have 'significant information' that could assist the district attorney's office.
The nurse reported that during her 24-hour care of Epstein at the Surrey Hotel in Manhattan, she 'experienced' what the victims went through, implying firsthand witness to concerning behavior.
Ghislaine Maxwell visited Epstein during this period of medical care in 2000.
The nurse delayed reporting for over 20 years due to HIPAA concerns as Epstein was her patient, but had since consulted attorneys about what she could legally disclose.
The caller, a professor of nursing, requested an in-person meeting to provide details, declining to share specific information over the phone.
